rounds.observation:
Welcome to the Trading Arena! You are Player 0 in this competitive resource exchange game.
Your goal is to maximize your wealth by strategically trading resources with your opponent.
Your current resource portfolio includes:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 6    Value: 5
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 20   Value: 8
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 18   Value: 16
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 9    Value: 22
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 25   Value: 33
Each turn provides an opportunity to negotiate with your trading partner.
To interact effectively, use these action commands:
  - '[Offer: 4 Wood, 1 Brick -> 2 Ore, 3 Wheat]': Format - [Offer: What_You_Give -> What_You_Want]
  - '[Accept]': Use this to accept any pending trade proposal.
  - '[Deny]': Use this to reject any pending trade proposal (this is the default response).
This trading session will continue for exactly 10 rounds.
rounds.response:
I’ve inventoried what both of us hold (based on the values shown), and my goal is to end the 10 rounds with the highest total-value sum.  
Right now my Ore is my most valuable resource (33 each), and I have the most of it. Brick is next-best (22 each) and I have only 9, so increasing Brick would give the biggest marginal value boost. Wheat is my cheapest (5 each), followed by Wood (8 each), so I’m willing to part with them if the exchange rate is good.

First-time offer to test the waters and acquire more Brick:

[Offer: 5 Wheat, 6 Wood -> 3 Brick]

rounds.response:
I’ve just seen that we’re starting Round 5 of 10 (three full rounds have passed and we’re now in the fifth).  
My current portfolio is:

Wheat 6 (5)  
Wood 20 (8)  
Sheep 18 (16)  
Brick 9 (22)  
Ore 25 (33)

Key observations
- Ore is my most valuable resource (33).  
- Brick is also high-value (22) and I’m relatively short on it (only 9).  
- Wheat is my least valuable and I have a decent surplus (6).  
- Player 1 has rejected every offer so far, so I need something simpler and more obviously beneficial to them while still moving value toward me.

Trade idea: I give away two of my lowest-value resources (Wheat & Wood) to acquire the higher-value Brick.

[Offer: 2 Wheat, 3 Wood -> 2 Brick]

rounds.response:
Let me assess the new proposal from Player 1.

Offer on the table  
Player 1 gives: 10 Brick (value = 10 × 22 = 220)  
Player 1 wants: 2 Wheat, 3 Wood, 1 Sheep  
My value given up = 2×5 + 3×8 + 1×16 = 10 + 24 + 16 = 50  

I’d receive 220 value for giving up only 50 value—a huge net gain (+170). Even after losing those resources, I’d still have 4 Wheat, 17 Wood, 17 Sheep, 19 Brick, and 25 Ore—completely workable distribution.

[Accept]

rounds.response:
I’ll quickly recap what just happened so we can move forward smartly.

What I gained from the last round  
+10 Brick ( value 22 × 10 =220 )

What I gave up  
–2 Wheat ( value 5 × 2  = –10 )  
–3 Wood ( value 8 × 3  = –24 )  
–1 Sheep ( value 16 ×1 = –16 )

Net value change: +170, so my total wealth jumped nicely and my Brick pile grew to 19 while Brick became Player 1’s scarcest resource.

Because Player 1 is now extremely short on Brick (we know they had at least 18 before, traded 10 away, then accepted none back) their willingness to pay premium for it should be high. Conversely I now have plenty of Brick (19) and very little Wheat ( I had 6, lost 2, = 4 remaining ). My other holdings right now are:  
Wheat 4, Wood 17, Sheep 17, Brick 19, Ore 25.

Next move  
I’ll offer them exactly what they’re most desperate for (Brick) in exchange for what I’m running low on (Wheat) and still value highly (Ore). Simultaneously I’ll toss in low-marginal-value Wood for them to sweeten the deal.

[Offer: 5 Brick, 2 Wood -> 3 Ore, 4 Wheat]
